Flint Hills Resources Longview, LLC (FHR) owns and operates a polypropylene process unit (polypropylene manufacturing) located near Longview, Harrison County, Texas and an associated propylene unloading area is located approximately two (2) miles west of the Polypropylene Process unit in Gregg County.     

FHR's Longview polypropylene process unit is enclaved within a large chemical complex owned by Eastman Chemical Company.  Although FHR owns the equipment that makes up the FHR Longview Facility, it leases the associated land from Eastman Chemicals.  Operators and emergency response activities are provided by Eastman under a contract agreement.  The FHR Longview Facility is the only industrial facility operated by FHR at the Eastman Chemical Company complex.  The land leased by FHR is surrounded by Eastman Chemical Company's other property.  

In previous RMP Submissions, the polypropylene process unit within Eastman was submitted by Eastman under their RMP since they provided operators and emergency response.   Eastman notified FHR that they will not be including our process in their RMP on their next update, due in November 2019.  Operators and Emergency Response in the Polypropylene Process unit is still supplied by Eastman by agreement.  The propylene unloading facility was part of FHR's original RMP, and this resubmission is updating that information as well.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.

The Flint Hills Resources Longview, LLC - Longview Facility (FHR) is located at 118 Huntsman Way in Longview, Texas. 

FHR is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while full

y complying with applicable laws and regulations. FHR's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.



2.1.2    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Longview unloading facility, operated by FHR, is a propylene unloading and storage facility located in Gregg County, Longview, Texas. The facility is operated for offloading propylene from railcars into a storage tank until transferred via pipeline to a nearby polymers plant. 

As part of its unloading and storage operations, the facility uses propylene, an EPA RMP covered chemical, in quantities greater than the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The facility consists of three double-sided railcar unloading racks for a total of six offloading spots, in addition to a storage tank, compressor system, and associated piping and instrumentation. Railcars are offloaded into the storage tank, and propylene is transferred via pump from the storage tank into a Department of Transportation (DOT) pipeline that transfers propylene to a nearby Polymers plant. The Longview facility does not have any EPA RMP-regulated toxic chemicals.

In addition to the propylene unloading, FHR owns and operates a Polypropylene Process unit located near Longview, Harrison County, Texas.  The Polypropylene Process unit is located approximately associated propylene unloading area is located approximately two (2) miles east of the propylene unloading facility.

The Flint Hills Resources Longview, LLC - Longview Facility (FHR) polypropylene process unit is located on the Eastman Longview Chemical Complex at 300 Kodak Boulevard in Longview, Texas. Given that FHR is the owner of the unit and Eastman is the operator, the policies applied at the unit are a combination of FHR and Eastman policies. 

As the owner of the unit, FHR is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. FHR's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The polypropylene process unit at the Eastman Longview Complex, owned by FHR and operated by Eastman, is a polypropylene production unit. The polypropylene unit is integrated into Eastman Operations safety and emergency response practices and processes, and in the past has been considered part of the Eastman facility for purposes of compliance with the RMP regulation. The polypropylene produced at the unit is primarily supplied to industrial customers. 

As part of its polypropylene production, the facility uses two EPA RMP covered chemicals -propylene and propane - in quantities greater than the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The Longview facility does not have any EPA RMP-regulated toxic chemicals.

Polypropylene Process Unit Emergency Response:  At the polypropylene process unit facility, the Eastman Plant Manager is responsible for coordinating emergency actions. The Eastman facility is contractually in charge of providing emergency support to the FHR process unit. A written and specific Emergency Response Plan coordinated with local officials is in place for the facility. The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

Eastman maintains a comprehensive site emergency response plan. Employees train annually on the plan as they prepare for a plant wide drill. Key elements of the emergency response plan as it relates to the community emergency response include, but are not limited to, the following: 

?    Eastman maintains an emergency response team whose members are specifically trained and equipped to respond to emergencies such as leaks, spills, fires, etc. 

?    Eastman emergency response personnel use a computerized modeling system to predict the concentration and location of any vapor cloud resulting from a hazardous vapor release using real time weather information. 

?    Response is coordinated with emergency response agencies in the community via a Field Command Post and the Eastman emergency response center. 

?    Eastman maintains a community emergency notification plan. For events that might impact the community, a direct line to the City of Longview dispatcher is utilized. The dispatcher contacts the Gregg County Sheriff's office and Harrison County Sheriff's office. 

?    Emergency response personnel are regularly trained to comply with all federal, state, and local requirements. 

?    An automated community telephone emergency notification system, "Code Red", is available to provide quick, concise emergency information to Eastman's nearby neighbors if an ev

Both areas (unloading and process unit) are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119, and regulated under EPA Risk Management Program 40 CFR Part 68 - Program Level 3 requirements.

2.1.3    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards adopted by FHR.  These standards include:

?    Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 

?    Operating and maintaining the assets such that unintentional releases are minimized.

?    Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.

?    Correcting findings identified in regular audits of the facility.



FHR is committed to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes. The Longview facility adheres to process safety policies, guidelines, and best practices that have been developed based on company and industry experience over the years. FHR's practice is to implement the controls necessary to prevent releases of regulated substances to the environment. However, if a release does occur, trained FHR personnel will respond, to control and contain the incident. Details on the emergency response program are outlined in Section 2.1.6.

Additionally, Eastman policies applicable to the unit are summarized in the Eastman "Principles of Safety" document. Eastman conducts all aspects of its business in a manner that provides for the safety of employees, contractors, communities, customers, and the environment. The Eastman safety process consists of six main steps: 

?    Hazard identification, prevention and control 

?    Safe design and construction 

?    Safety

and health education and training 

?    Employee involvement, accountability, and responsibility 

?    Inspection, testing, repair and preventative maintenance (mechanical integrity) 

?    Systematic evaluation for continual improvement 



Details of the Eastman accident prevention efforts are contained in the Texas Operations General Operating Procedures, the Texas Operations Authorized Safe Practice Manual, and the Standard Operating Procedures of the unit. These document specific practices and procedures to help ensure the safety of the employees, contractors, community, and the environment. 

Details of the emergency response efforts are contained in the mentioned documents, as well as the Texas Operations Emergency Plan. This plan specifies the responsibilities and duties of Eastman personnel during emergencies and potential emergencies. These responsibilities and duties provide for the prompt mobilization of the company's resources, including both personnel and equipment in an emergency situation. These plans are updated routinely, and are periodically reviewed in their entirety.



2.1.4    Prevention Program

The FHR Longview Facility (unloading and process unit) is operating under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees and emphasis on safety has contributed to process safety.  The facility has had no RMP chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases, as part of a detailed prevention program.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

?    Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in power supply to the process control system by having a backup power generator.

?    Providing preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program to

ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.

?    Minimizing the possibility of a release of propane and propylene, using shutdown interlocks installed on process equipment.

?    Reducing the severity of fires when operating automatic and manual deluge systems.

?    Reducing the risk of overfilling by including level alarms and/or indicators on the storage tank.

?    Implementing operating procedures for unloading and transfer operations.

?    Installing combustible gas detectors in the facility.



2.1.5    Five-Year Accident History

EPA requires that all incidents involving regulated chemicals that resulted in any off-site impact or significant on-site impact be reported in this document. Within the last five years (October 15, 2014 - October 15, 2019), there were no releases of hazardous materials that met the criteria for an RMP accident.



2.1.6    Emergency Response Program

Due to separate operating areas between FHR for the Propylene Unloading and within Eastman for the Polypropylene Process Unit (operated by Eastman operators), there are two separate Emergency Response Programs.    The dates in the Emergency Response Section 9 are the most recent dates between the two areas.    The specific information for each area is included in this executive summary section below.



Propylene Unloading Emergency Response:  The propylene unloading facility continues to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the local Longview Fire Department and Gregg County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). As appropriate, the Texas State Police, local hospitals and other coordinating agencies also continue to be involved in emergency response for the facility.  The FHR Longview Site Manager is responsible for coordinating emergency actions at the unloading facility.

Propylene Unloading Emergency Response (ER) Training/Drills are held regularly at FHR, and most recent drill was 7/1/19.

2.1.7    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

?    The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of changes made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.

?    The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure 

?    timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.

?    The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

?    Hazard Analysis: Continual identification of potential hazards, and prompt implementation of corrective action are done in accordance with applicable regulations and as a matter of company policy. 

?    Incident Investigation: Prompt, thorough investigation of all significant incidents and near-misses are conducted and findings are shared across the company. 

?    Benchmarking: Through our trade association, the American Chemistry Council, and through other cooperative efforts, such as
the Center for Chemical Process Safety, we continually evaluate our safety program and processes against the best in the world, with the goal of continual improvement.
